Award.AwardTitle: Integer flows, circular flow indices and modulo orientations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the principal investigator's research in graph theory, and specifically flows, coloring, and connectivity in graphs. This area is closely related to computer science, operations research, data mining, and the neurosciences, where graphs are abstract mathematical notions used to model networks, such as communication and transportation networks, social networks, surveillance data, pathways in bioinformatics, and neural-networks. Various graph coloring problems have been considered as effective models for radio channel assignment/distribution, and flow problems originally arise in optimizing traffic or network. This project is concerned with structural problems in networks.

Integer flow theory, introduced by Tutte as a dual of the graph/map coloring problem, is the major subject of this proposed project. Recently, the principal investigator (collaborating with Lovasz, Thomassen and Wu) successfully proved that every 6-edge-connected graph admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow, and (collaborating with Thomassen and the team at WVU) discovered a relation between strongly connected orientations and circular flow indices. The principal investigator will continue his research work in this direction by determining the flow indices for graphs with various connectivity, investigating flows of graphs embedded on non-orientable surfaces, studying modulo orientations of less connected graphs for better solutions to Tutte's flow conjectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studies in graph theory is closely related to computer science, operational research, data mining and neurosciences. A graph is an abstract mathematical notion used to model networks, such as communication/transportation networks, social networks, surveillance data, pathways in bioinformatics, neuron-networks, etc.. Various graph coloring problems have been considered as effective models for radio channel assignment/distribution, and flow problems originally arise in optimizing traffic or network. This proposal is concerned with structural problems of networks: Why do some networks possess certain specific properties, and others do not? Especially, when the reliability (connectivity) of a network decreases, certain flow patterns may disappear.  

Integer flow theory, introduced by Tutte as a dual of the graph/map coloring problem, is the major subject of this proposed project. Recently, the PI (collaborating with Lovasz, Thomassen and Wu) successfully proved that every 6-edge-connected graph admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow, and (collaborating with Thomassen and the team at WVU) discovered a relation between strongly connected orientations and circular flow indices.  The PI has been continuing his research work in the area of Tutte's flow theory and its related areas, such as, the famous Cycle Double Cover Conjecture, Berge-Fulkerson Conjecture.

Data science is an important application of graph theory. The PI has been extending his theoretical research to the studies of data structure.  Along this direction, the PI (and his team) developed software for community discovery from Facebook data, pattern recognition of neuron networks, etc.   

During the support of this grant, the PI has published 17 refereed journal papers (plus some submitted papers).  Some of them are in the theoretical direction of the project, some of them are applications/software development for data sciences.
